description.narrative: Functional Literacy Project in Cameroon is an extended project for successful continuum liaison between Wycliffe Finland (WRK) and Cameroon Association for Bible Translation + Literacy (CABTAL).The project will enhance the living conditions of the indigeno us Cameroonian young people in 11 different language communities. They have often poor education because of language issues. Therefore especially many young women never finished the school and get easily marginalized. They often lack basic life skills are unaware of their rights and become easily abused.The program is already established in 46 villages where some 2000 young adults have gained skills to develop their social and economic status. The curriculum and the learning material has been developed into all the 11 languages involved in the project. The project has attracted neighboring communities and the best practices are already shared with several communities. The second phase of the project is important in order to ensure sustainability and smooth e xit of the project.This project seeks:1. to empower some 4 240 young marginalized people mainly women who will learn skills to improve their social and economic status through the program. In this second phase of the project there will be 57 Functional lit eracy classes each year where the learners study issues about better life.2. to ensure sustainability of the started Functional literacy program in 11 ethnic communities. The implementation responsibilities of local programs will be handed over to the loca l Community Based Organizations local education body and elite will be engaged to the program. Advocacy measures will be focused towards the responsible government bodies and elite to ensure their support to the program. The local organizations (11) will b e trained to carry on the implementation part of the project.Wycliffe Finland is an organization who is specialized to mother tongue education programs in indigenous communities. CABTAL is an organization in Cameroon who has different language development projects in 68 indigenous language communities. This project helps to build their capacity to facilitate locally run education programs.
